In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB‟s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Philippines, through the Bureau of Local Government Finance 
(BLGF), asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide capacity development technical 
assistance (TA) to support local government revenue generation and land administration and 
management  reforms.  These  are  to  strengthen  social  and  economic  development, 
environmental management, and governance of local government units (LGUs). The TA is 
included in ADB‟s 2010–2012 country operations business plan for the Philippines.1 During the 
15–29 September fact-finding mission, the government and ADB reached an understanding on 
the TA impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, 
and terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Land titles are important assets that can be traded or used as collateral for loans, which 
in turn can be transformed into capital for economic activities. Land information management 
has been neglected in the Philippines. As a result, about half of the estimated 24 million land 
parcels  remain  untitled,  of  which  7  million  to  8  million  are  estimated  to  be  residential.               
The country‟s record of land ownership weakens security of tenure, opens the system to abuse, 
and denies government and citizens a complete view of land ownership. This results in disputes, 
and inefficient social and economic services and environmental management. The lack of land 
tenure security ultimately inhibits the ability to invest and hampers the country‟s economic 
growth. Recent attempts to establish a unified system for property registration and public land 
management have led to drafting of the Land Administration Reform Act, which is one of the 17 
priority bills submitted to Congress in 2011. Oversight of the management of land information 
and  responsibility  for  land  classification,  surveys,  and  mapping  is  highly  fragmented.  The 
Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) is the primary agency involved in 
land titling issuing about 100,000 patents a year. Other key national government agencies 
(NGAs) involved include the Registry of Deeds of the Land Registration Authority (LRA) and the 
Department of Finance (DOF), in particular BLGF.3 
 
3.  Lack of national standards and methods for valuation and limited training of valuation 
staff have led to the use of conflicting valuation methodologies, distorted real property values, 
politicized application of real property tax rates and assessments, limited access to public 
records, and limited use of information technology in appraisals. Outdated real property values 
because of irregular updating of schedules of market values (SMVs) by LGUs, combined with 
poor collection efficiency, have resulted in low revenue collections from the real property tax.      
In many LGUs, SMVs substantially lag true market values, often as much as 200%–500%.        
In 2007, collection efficiency was only 27% in provinces and 68% in cities. Thus the ability of 
LGUs to raise revenue from real property taxes is severely hampered, and their corresponding 
expenditure for constituency welfare is much constrained.  
 
4.  TA funded by the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) for the 
Land Administration and Management Project 2 (LAMP2), specifically the Innovation Support 
                                                
1  ADB. 2009. Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2010–2012. Manila. The TA is included under the title 
Support to Policy Development on Decentralization and Local Governance. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB‟s website on 18 October 2010. 
3  DENR is responsible for titling, surveying, and sharing land information. The Registry of Deeds is responsible for 
registration and sharing of title information; and BLGF coordinates matters relating to property tax, i.e., valuation.

2   
Fund (ISF),4 shows that a demand-driven reform program focusing on the reform of processes 
for land administration and management (LAM) in policy, technical, and institutional areas can 
gain significant momentum within LGUs, even in a difficult policy environment. The TA worked 
simultaneously on these three aspects with new processes and technology developed under the 
existing legal framework, while changes to laws5 were pursued in parallel. Reforms were made 
to both the fiscal (property valuation and tax policy), and technical (surveying, mapping, land 
disposition, and land registration) property systems.  
 
5.  The current government states that tax administration reforms are a priority. LAMP2 
prepared a land sector development plan for submission by DENR and DOF partners to the 
National  Economic  and  Development  Authority  (NEDA)  for  inclusion  in  the  2011–2016            
Philippine Development Plan. In an August 2010 memorandum, the Department of Interior and 
Local  Government  (DILG)  states  that  it  recognizes  the  successful  implementation  and 
innovations  of  LAM  reforms,  and  supports  the  expansion  of  LGU-managed  LAM  reforms 
through LGU–NGA partnerships. It sees these as consistent with the thrusts of this government. 
Therefore, the revenue generation and land administration reforms initiated by LAMP2 will likely 
be included in the 2010–2016 plan. Particular emphasis will be placed on SMV-related reforms.  
 
6.  The self-assessment activity completion report and independent completion report both 
rate LAMP2 “successful.” Despite this, AusAID has informed the government that it will “pause” 
its assistance while awaiting formulation of its new country strategy paper expected to be 
finalized in 2011. The World Bank‟s major financial commitment to LAMP2 was for land titling 
and land services, but it increased its interest in the DOF valuation and taxation reforms as the 
project progressed. At the same time, the World Bank implemented the Local Government 
Finance Development Project within DOF‟s Municipal Development Fund Office.  
 
7.  Since 2004, ADB has supported the government's decentralization efforts through the 
Local Government Finance and Budget Reform Program, which was designed as a program 
cluster with provision for program lending and TA.6 Various TA projects have helped continue 
the policy dialogue, address gaps and constraints in the five core program areas, as well as 
develop capacity.7 Lessons from the program include (i) persist with long-term commitment; (ii) 
ensure the government drives the program; (iii) engage intensively over time especially  to 
develop capacity (as broadly defined) at all levels; and (iv) support coordination efforts between 
central agencies and LGUs. ADB has been coordinating with the development partners through 
the  Working  Group  for  Decentralization  and  Local  Government  under  the  Philippines 
Development Forum.  
                                                
4  The ISF ran from February 2006 to June 2010 and initially reached 16 LGUs across the country. LGUs received 
small grants to be used for procurement of equipment, training, and operations. In parallel, the ISF helped with 
access to national government data, updates, and training. 
5  Congress has passed two laws developed by LAMP2: the Real Estate Service Act (Republic Act No. 9646,           
16 July 2009) and the Free Patent Law (Republic Act No. 0023, otherwise known as the Act Authorizing the 
Issuance of Free Patents to Residential Lands, 22 March 2010).  
6  Subprogram 1 covered 2006–2007 and provided a comprehensive policy framework and matrix that, while helping 
finalize  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  sought  to  broaden  policy  reforms  in  five  core  areas:  (i) 
intergovernmental fiscal relations; (ii) fiscal management, planning, and public expenditure management; (iii) LGU 
performance  measurement  and  service  delivery;  (iv)  credit  financing;  and  (v)  local  own  source  revenues. 
Subprogram 2 covered 2008–2009 and continued the work in the five target areas, with intensification of effort and 
finalization of a number of key actions commenced in subprogram 1. 
7  The most relevant for this TA is: ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to the Republic of the Philippines for Local 
Governance and Fiscal Management. Manila (TA 4778-PHI, for $1.8 million).

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will expand the delivery of economic and social services in participating LGUs. 
Its outcome will be participating LGUs use improved land management and administration 
systems, including property valuation and taxation innovations, to generate increased local 
government revenues.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Drawing on careful deliberation based on the experiences of the ISF program, a pilot 
approach8 will be adopted comprising the following four components. 
 
10.  Institutionalization of LAM good practice models. At least two LGUs will be selected 
based on their demonstrated capacity, leadership, and proven track record in specific systems 
or technologies. These LGUs will be provided with technical assistance and capability building 
to ensure their development as good practice models in the LAM training network. The LGUs 
will link with the Center for LAM at the Land Management Bureau and serve as the center‟s 
training hubs. This component will also involve strengthening the LGUs‟ front desks, information 
offices, and/or the LGU land services office to provide a business one-stop shop. Beyond 
support to the core revenue and land information functions, these LGUs will be supported in 
revising their SMVs, and land management and investment plans to complete reform of local 
major land and finance-related systems. This will be achieved using a “whole of government” 
approach. 
 
11.  Extension of LAM activities. The activities will focus on two of the five LGUs9 that have 
received ISF support since September 2009. To date, support has focused on the establishment 
of the spatial land system and/or geographic information system (GIS), or the electronic tax 
revenue and collection system. Further support is required to ensure the full operation of these 
basic unified land information and revenue systems and their adoption of reforms on valuation, 
land  management,  and  investment  planning.  Selection  will  be  based  on  assessment  of 
performance, likelihood of success, and readiness to expand existing small grants. Parallel 
assistance will be provided to the LGU LAM agency partners. 
 
12.  Provision of small LAM grants to three new LGUs. This will entail the competitive 
selection of new LGUs through the Leagues of Provinces, Cities, and Municipalities, and the 
interagency  grant  awards  committee.  Criteria  include  leadership, track  record  in  managing 
interagency cooperation, project preparedness, and commitment of the LGU and its partners to 
LAM  reform.  LGUs  will  commit  to  set  up  the  appropriate  organization  structures  and 
mechanisms, and to provide at least a 25% counterpart fund to the grant. Coverage may be 
expanded to include progressive and deserving fourth to fifth class LGUs.10  
 
                                                
8  Four groups of LGUs are to receive grants for a total of eight cities and municipalities and one province. The 
demand-driven nature of the project means that the number of LGUs expected to take up each of the five possible 
output types cannot be estimated at this stage. 
9  Dipolog, Iriga, Laoag, Oroquieta, and Tayabas. 
10 This refers to the government‟s classification system for LGUs as specified in the DoF Order No. 23-08 effective 29 
July 2008. According to this, fourth class municipalities have an average annual income of P25 million–P35 million 
while fifth class municipalities have an average annual income of P15 million–P25 million during the last 3 calendar 
years. Fourth class cities have an average annual income of P160 million–P240 million while fifth class cities have 
an average annual income of P80 million–P160 million during the past 3 years.

4   
13.  Provision of support to one provincial and one municipal LGU. The objective is to 
strengthen the role of the province in rolling out LAM initiatives. A provincial LGU will be 
selected where an ISF-supported LGU is located that has demonstrated capacity for replication 
of LAM technologies, and good leadership and a track record in interagency cooperation and 
collaboration. This provincial LGU will have committed to partnerships between the LGUs and 
their LAM agency partners. A counterpart fund of at least 25% is required. A municipality within 
the province will also be assisted to serve as a pilot for a provincial ISF LGU model. 
 
14.  Through the pilots, the TA will achieve five outputs. 
 
15.  Output 1. Participating LGUs and partner national LAM agencies collaborate actively, 
effectively, and efficiently in the delivery of improved LAM services to the public. This entails the 
selection of LGUs, the setting up of an interagency LAM steering committee to provide policy 
and  program  directions  and  implementation  oversight  (to  ensure  complementation  across 
agencies  and  information  sharing),  human  resources  development  and  management,  LAM 
policy development and advocacy, advocacy on governance of LAM revenues and expenditures, 
and the establishment of a LAM services office (one-stop shop) to improve delivery of services 
to the various stakeholders.   
 
16.  Output  2.  Unified  land  information  systems  are  established  and  operating  in 
participating LGUs and partner LAM agencies. This includes the development of a unified land 
information system; TA and capability building; the provision of systems and facilities enabling 
access by the stakeholders to cross-referenced, accurate, and up-to-date parcel-based land 
and related information; the installation of a valuation database and information system; and the 
revision of the SMVs and revenue information system.  
 
17.  Output 3. Property valuation policies and practices are updated in participating mature 
LGUs. This includes TA, technology transfer and adoption of valuation systems developed by 
BLGF, revision of the SMVs, and use of a state-of-the-art GIS for a parcel-based revenue 
information system. This is expected to broaden the local revenue and tax base, and establish a 
more efficient and transparent revenue collection system. 
 
18.  Output 4. Zoning plans and comprehensive land use plans are revised (only for mature 
participating  LGUs)  with  stakeholder  participation.  This  will  link  components  (systems  and 
database development to generate spatial information and local revenue) to land management 
and investment planning to be collectively used to improve social and economic development 
and environmental management. TA and training will be provided for the management and 
utilization of revenues generated for social and economic development.   
 
19.  Output 5. Land tenure status of participating LGUs is assessed and appropriate land 
tenure improvement, and financing strategies and plans are prepared. This may entail surveying 
and  tax  mapping  in  rural  and  urban  areas  designed  to  improve  tenure  security  thereby 
expanding real property tax and business tax collection.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,600,000.00 equivalent, $1,500,000.00 of 
which  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction,  and 
administered by ADB. LGUs involved in the pilot projects, will finance $85,000.00 equivalent as 
counterpart funds (in kind) while the national government will contribute $15,000.00. The cost 
estimates and financing plan is provided in Appendix 2.

5 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  As the executing agency, BLGF will oversee the TA project and provide leadership, as 
well  as  policy  and  program  direction  to  ensure  efficient  implementation.  BLGF  will  be 
responsible for the adoption of appropriate arrangements to operationalize the project including 
the establishment of an interagency governing board and coordination with the ADB project 
officer, the consulting team, and the project LGUs. An interagency governing board chaired 
alternately by DENR, DILG, and DOF, and comprising officials from BLGF; DENR; DILG; LRA; 
NEDA; the leagues of provinces, cities, and municipalities; nongovernment organizations; and 
the private sector will be established.11 The implementing agencies will include BLGF, DENR, 
and LRA‟s Registry of Deeds.12 Arrangements for LGU grantees are provided in Appendix 4.  
22.  Based on track record, a consultant firm13 will be responsible for overall management of 
implementation  to  ensure  compliance  with  all  policy  actions,  program  administration, 
disbursements, and maintenance of all project records. ADB will engage the consultant using 
the single-source selection method in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for 4 person-months of 
international consulting and 162 person-months of national consulting are in Appendix 3. The 
consultant will design, procure, and install the pilot facilities under the TA in accordance with 
ADB‟s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the 
TA  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB‟s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook          
(2010, as amended from time to time).14  
 
23.  The TA will be implemented from July 2011 to June 2013. The expected outputs and 
outcome evaluation, and key experiences gained and methodologies developed under the TA 
will be disseminated through websites, an LGU forum, and the Center for LAM at the Land 
Management Bureau at DENR. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000.00  to  the 
Government of the Republic of the Philippines to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction for Support to Local Government Revenue Generation and Land 
Administration Reforms, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
11  This board will be responsible for the selection of beneficiary LGUs and for coordinating implementation across 
stakeholder agencies. It will meet at least twice a year to monitor progress and oversee implementation. ADB will 
participate in the meetings as an observer. Depending on the agreements, other development partners such as 
AusAID and the Japan International Cooperation Agency may be invited as observers. Participating LGUs, through 
their local steering committees, will be responsible for program implementation and report progress to the 
consultant firm.  
12  Each implementing agency will be responsible for coordinating implementation of project operations relating to its 
specific functions. DENR will be responsible for titling, surveying, and sharing land information. LRA‟s Registry of 
Deeds will be responsible for registration and sharing of title information, and BLGF will coordinate on matters 
relating to property tax, i.e., valuation. 
13  Land Equity International, a consultant firm previously engaged by AusAID on a competitive basis (LAMP2 was 
contracted after public tendering in 2005) and with a track record in implementing LAMP2 will be engaged under 
the TA using single source selection. BLGF has given the consultant firm a positive assessment. 
14 Upon TA completion, the consultant will turn over equipment to the LGUs. The consultant will submit a certificate of 
turnover or disposal to ADB in line with ADB procedures.

10  Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consulting firm will organize and manage two teams: a project management team 
(positions A–G) and a technical team (H–I). The project management team comprises one 
project director, four core staff, and two administrative and finance assistants. The technical 
team comprises four core technical staff with different specializations. 
 
2.  The project management team will serve as the operations unit for day-to-day project 
implementation; the technical team will provide technical guidance. The project management 
team  will  be  primarily  responsible  for  ensuring  that  the  project  objectives  and  targets  are 
achieved, all policies are complied with, and appropriate standards and guidelines for program 
administration, procurement, disbursements, accounts, and maintenance of all program records 
are in place. The team will: 
 
(i)  manage and administer day-to-day operations and implementation of the project; 
(ii)  review, assess, and endorse local government unit (LGU) project proposals and 
project design documents; 
(iii)  draft, negotiate, approve, and sign agreements with each LGU; and administer 
the agreements (10 LGUs); 
(iv)  provide  fund  administration  and  management  services  for  the  grant  fund 
including fund releases to LGUs, and procurement and contracting of services for 
the LGU grantees; 
(v)  provide management support and technical assistance to the LGU grantees; 
(vi)  plan, coordinate, manage, and evaluate training programs suitable for staff of 
grantees; 
(vii)  conduct periodic project reviews, evaluations, and quality assessments for all 
LGU projects; 
(viii)  serve  as  secretariat  and  provide  technical  and  administrative  support  to the 
interagency governing board; 
(ix)  liaise  with  key  development  partners;  national  agencies;  the  leagues  of 
provinces, cities, and municipalities; and other stakeholders; and 
(x)  prepare for Asian Development Bank (ADB) briefings and the necessary reports, 
submissions,  and  documentation  of  the  grant  fund  utilization  and  project 
operation and implementation progress. 
 
A.  Project Director (international, 4 person-months, intermittent,  July 2011–June 2013) 
3.  The  project  director  will  have  extensive  international  experience  in  project 
implementation  and  more  than  10  years  experience  in  managing  projects  related  to  land 
management and administration and multidisciplinary teams. The director will:  
 
(i)  be responsible for overall supervision of the team and administration of grant 
funds,  in  particular  sign  all  agreements  with  LGU  grantees  and  contract  of 
services procured under the grant in consonance with approved guidelines; 
(ii)  monitor overall performance of the project and assist the grant manager in more 
complex problem solving; 
(iii)  visit the project at least once per quarter to assess progress, including the impact 
of the application of the new methods and technologies (apply knowledge of 
world‟s best practice to identify areas of possible improvement in at least two 
LGUs per visit); 
(iv)  review internal and external audit reports on the quality systems and recommend 
any necessary responses; 
(v)  review major reports and submit consolidated reports to ADB; and

Appendix 3  13 
data capture, processing, updating, storage, retrieval and sharing of data, and 
other application systems; 
(iv)  track the progress of GIS work, output, and milestones in the participating LGUs; 
(v)  provide overall guidance and technical inputs in the development of a customized 
LGU GIS operations manual that will include GIS and information technology 
infrastructure  design  layout  and  connectivity;  strategy  in  data  capture, 
development of GIS themes, updating, storage and retrieval, security protocols; 
GIS capability building and training; GIS organization and management; GIS 
operational sustainability; and 
(vi)  coordinate with other information technology advisers to ensure networking and 
connectivity of the various LGU LAM systems. 
 
G.  Property  Valuation  and  Taxation  (national,  5  person-months,  intermittent,                          
   November 2011-October 2012) 
 
9.  The  consultant  must  have  practical  knowledge  and  broad  experience  in  property 
valuation and Philippine tax laws, policies, practices, and processes; and at least 5 years 
experience in tax reform and cost-recovery practices. Activities include: 
 
(i)  identify LGU needs and limitations based on a review of the emerging special 
requirements of treasurers on tax compliance determination and simulate the 
effect of various real property tax policies to LGUs; 
(ii)  coordinate with resource persons on the LGUs‟ existing computerized revenue 
system and tax mapping, and consider necessary and other linkages to other 
LGU systems such as digital cadastral database; 
(iii)  evaluate the impact of revising SMVs and assist the LGUs in determining the 
appropriate tax rates so as not to undermine current real property tax collection; 
(iv)  develop a financial model to determine and/or demonstrate the impact of the 
recommended  tax  reforms  on  the  government  and  taxpayers,  specifically  in 
terms of government revenues and taxpayer‟s tax burden; 
(v)  take the lead in capability-building of LGUs to revise SMVs aligned with the 
actual market; 
(vi)  provide training on modern appraisal methods; 
(vii)  conduct field research on actual sales and rentals and compilation of a database 
of reference properties (valuation database information system); 
(viii)  reference sales and rentals to an adopted reference date using new guidelines 
on mass appraisal to make the new SMV; tax policy study to set the approach to 
phasing in of any large tax increases; buy-in of the LGU Council, Bureau of 
Internal Revenue, business, NGOs, and various publics on valuation reform; and 
(ix)  provide follow-up support to the LGUs. 
 
H.  Monitoring  and  Evaluation  and  External  Evaluation  (national,  2  person-months,               
September 2011-September 2012)    
 
10.  The consultant must have at least 10 years extensive experience in all aspects of project 
monitoring and evaluation, including end-of-project and external evaluation. Activities include: 
 
(i)  review the project design and monitoring framework, other relevant documents  
(if the project design and monitoring framework needs revisiting, then this should 
be part of the tasks also). (Note: The project plan should be available as the 
basis of the monitoring and evaluation [M&E] framework and system); 
(ii)  develop  the  M&E  framework  which  contains  (a)  elaboration  of  indicators  of 
project outcomes and impacts; (b) roles and responsibilities of key managers,

14  Appendix 3 
staff, and stakeholders; (c) identification of critical questions and hypotheses 
requiring more investigation; (d) monitoring and reporting flows, formats, and 
contents; (e) evaluation work required and/or design of evaluation studies; and  
(f) M&E tools and procedures; 
(iii)  train staff on the use of M&E tools and develop their capacity for implementation 
of the M&E framework; 
(iv)  orient key managers on the M&E framework, and its use in steering the project or 
for decision-making in the project; 
(v)  review the performance of the LGUs in implementing their ADB grant projects 
including  assessment  of  project  designs,  and  prospects  for  sustainability, 
effectiveness  of  management  arrangements;  and  document  early  benefits  to 
LGUs, partners, communities, and other stakeholders; 
(vi)  assess  the  overall  effectiveness  of  the  ADB  project  in  promoting  land 
administration and management (LAM) and fiscal reforms and broadening the 
base for adoption of LAM technologies;  
(vii)  examine  how  the  LGU  projects  contribute  to  improving  accountability, 
transparency, and promotion of gender equality in the provision of services; 
(viii)  compile major lessons and make recommendations on key matters, such as 
increasing  the  likelihood  of  better  performance,  achieving  desired  outcomes, 
improving support to LGU projects, improving linkages and complementation with 
similar  government  projects,  strengthening  participation  of  national  agencies, 
LGUs and leagues, promoting exchange among LGUs and project partners, and 
the potential of implementation of the long-term program including loans; 
(ix)  forecast any effective wider and possibly longer kind of intervention that would 
meet the objective of allowing an expansion of the program to other LGUs based 
on a needs-driven approach; and   
(x)  identify likely functional areas for the next phase.  
 
I.  Land Management and Investment Planning (national, 6 person-months, intermittent,  
October 2011-April 2013)  
 
11.  The  consultant  should  be  a  licensed  urban  environmental  planner,  with  extensive 
experience in land use planning and management as a trainer and in development investment 
packages for LGUs. Activities include: 
 
(i)  coordinate with the Housing and Land Use Regulatory Board on requirements 
and guidelines for land use planning (CLUP) and investment plan preparation; 
(ii)  after a field review of existing CLUPs and investment plans, develop a framework 
for developing CLUPs and investment plans; 
(iii)  prepare  workshop  agenda  and  materials  for  CLUP  and  investment  plan 
development; 
(iv)  conduct LGU CLUP and investment plan cluster workshops at a demonstration 
site in a mature LGU; 
(v)  undertake hands-on training on new insights and experiences in land-use and 
development  planning  with  the  key  LGU  personnel  involved  in  CLUP  and 
investment plan preparation and revision; 
(vi)  undertake field visits to selected mature LGUs and assist them in preparing a 
work  plan  that  schedules  principal  tasks  and  resource  requirements  in  the 
formulation of CLUPs and investment plans; and 
(vii)  pilot the development of a priority investment package for the LGU.

Appendix 4  15 
ARRANGEMENTS FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT UNIT GRANTEES 
 
1.  Local government units (LGUs) to receive grants from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)-assisted project will be competitively selected. They will provide a minimum of 25% local 
counterpart funding for particular activities not covered by the grant. 
 
2.  LGU grantees will be responsible for the following: 
(i)  implement the ADB grant-assisted project based on the approved design and 
monitoring framework and consistent with the approved land administration and 
management (LAM) medium-term development program and/or plan;  
(ii)  provide the necessary local leadership, management, and reporting of the project, 
including the designation of a suitable project coordinator, coordinating closely 
with the grant unit and local project partners, and rigorously acquitting project 
expenditures;  
(iii)  provide counterpart funding as in the approved project design document; 
(iv)  establish an interagency local steering committee through a memorandum of 
agreement  and  operate  the  committee  for  the  duration  of  the  project.                
The  committee  will  be  chaired  by  the  local  chief  executive  and  comprise 
representatives from the LGU; LAM line agencies of Bureau of Internal Revenue; 
Department  of  Agrarian  Reform,  Department  of  Environment  and  Natural 
Resources, Registry of Deeds, Department of Interior and Local Government; 
Association of Geodetic Engineers and/or a representative from civil society. The 
local steering committee will serve as the LGU  advisory council and as the 
policy-making body in the implementation of the grant project in the LGU; and 
(v)  organize a project implementation unit and designate appropriate LGU personnel 
through the issuance of an executive order. The designation of key personnel 
particularly the project manager and/or coordinator will be mutually agreed by the 
LGU and the grant management team and will be subject to a performance 
review from time to time. The project implementation unit will take care of the 
day-to-day operation and implementation of the grant-assisted project and serve 
as secretariat to the local steering committee.     
 
3.  In  addition,  the  LGU  pilot  for  Institutionalization  of  Best  Practice  Model  will  be 
responsible for: 
(i)  ensuring completion of demonstrable and replicable technology and best practice 
models; 
(ii)  serving as a training hub for mature LAM technologies and best practices for 
other LGU grantees of the project; 
(iii)  facilitating dissemination and spread of best practice model to other LGUs; and 
(iv)  demonstrating applications of gains from previous LAM activities to progress the 
valuation  and  real  property  tax  administration,  revenue  management,  land 
management, and investment programming. 
 
4.  Two LGUs selected for deepening of initial LAM reform activities will pursue completion 
of a unified land information system, and pursue real property valuation and taxation reform 
initiatives  
 
5.  New  entrant  LGUs  will  include  in  their  project  plans:  local  LAM  governance 
improvement; installation of a unified land information system in the LGU in coordination with 
national LAM agencies; and adoption of property valuation and taxation reforms for revenue 
generation.
